title: Cranham Woods Walking Route

images.title: Bob Embleton / Cranham Wood
images.caption: Close to the steep edge of the scarp slope of the Cotswold escarpment. Honey coloured Cotswold stones from a crumbling field boundary are scattered across the field in the foreground. Looking north west towards Buckholt wood in the distance.

images.title: Philip Halling / Cottage near Cranham
images.caption: Cottage on the edge of Cranham Wood on the road to the east of the village of Cranham

images.title: Philip Halling / Silver Birch on Cranham Common
images.caption: Silver birch tree on Cranham Common viewed from the road above the village. Buckholt Wood can be seen in the backbround.

images.title: Philip Halling / Cranham viewed from the east
images.caption: Cranham viewed from the east. Part of the village of Cranham viewed from the Common to the east of the village.

images.title: Colin Travis / Buckholt Woods
images.caption: Buckholt Woods Nature reserve. These woods are located just to the west of Cranham Wood

images.title: Philip Halling / The Cotswold Way in Buckholt Wood
images.caption: The Cotswold Way waymarker in Buckholt Wood

description: This circular woodland walk in the Cotswolds visits Cranham Woods, Buckholt Woods and Coopers Hill. These large peaceful woods have miles of walking trails through attractive Beech woodland. Cyclists can try a series of downhill mountain bike trails. The walk starts from the parking area at the southern end of the woods near Cranham. You then head through Buckholt Wood towards Cooper's Hill, site of the Cheese Rolling event held on the Spring Bank Holiday which involves locals chasing a large round cheese down a near-vertical grass slope. The route then heads through Cooper's Hill Woods before returning to the car park. If you would like to extend your walk then you could visit the nearby Prinknash Abbey Park or climb Painswick Beacon for wonderful views over the Cotswolds. Much of this walk makes use of the Cotswold Way National Trail so you could also continue east along the trail through Witcombe Wood to Birdlip Hill and the lovely Crickley Hill Country Park .

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: Just to the east of the woods you could pay a visit to the noteable Golden Heart Inn. This historic inn dates from the 16th century and includes an attractive interior with a cosy log fire. Outside there's a delightful patio area with views overlooking the valley. You can find it at Nettleton Bottom, Birdlip with a postcode of GL4 8LA for your sat navs.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The woods are a nice place for a dog walk and the Golden Heart Inn mentioned above is also dog friendly. They also provide treats on the bar for your furry friend.

display_address: Withches Tump, Sanatorium Road, Cranham, Stroud, Gloucestershire, England, GL4 8HP, United Kingdom
